text: A vast field of stars. The gas giant Neptune slowly spins into view. Brilliant and blue and cold against the void.
stands out against the planet, tiny against Neptune's sca
to discern the hard angles of a man-made craft. A ship. N longer dwarfed by the planet, the scale of the vessel eme a vast labyrinth of steel. Its shadow swallows all in darkness.
Shafts of Neptune's blue light enter through windows,  illuminate debris suspended in the zero-gravity environme shards of metal and glass. MOVE from the Corridor into:

A cockpit for three. Neptune's blue light fills the chamb reflects off immobile particles in the air. Thick quartz  windows look down at Neptune. The cockpit lights are dark but for one blinking red light. An emergency beacon. Under-floor lights go on. The strobe of the red light reveals a man floating at the helm, slowly spinning. He is dead, perfectly preserved in the cold vacuum of space. His eyes are empty black pits a his mouth hangs open in a scream: DR. WILLIAM WEIR.

Weir opens his eyes, waking from dream. Sweat beads his  ascetic, etched face. Many years a scientist. He turns on the bedside lamp, revealing a couple's apartm Decorated by a woman, but Weir is alone, unless you count photographs. His nightstand looks like a shrine to a beau woman. Weir reaches to the stand. Picks up...

The woman appears thin and haggard and wears a small brav smile. Weir lies back on the bed. Looks at the photo. Presses it his forehead and closes his eyes. Trying to be with her,  just one more time.
(whisper) I miss you.

Weir stands in front of the bathroom mirror, shaving with straight-razor. The mirror reveals the bathtub just behin him. DRIP, DRIP, DRIP... Weir turns to stare at the bathtub. Water wells up at the mouth of the tub's faucet, grows impossibly large, falls. DRIP. Weir turns back to his shaving.
Weir stands in the kitchenette, staring at the microwave it cooks his breakfast.
Weir stands before his window, chewing his oatmeal  mechanically, forcing himself to swallow. He reaches out open the blinds...
as the blinds pull aside, revealing Weir, upside-down. ROTATE AND PULL BACK...
Weir's window is just one of many in a space station, a  delicate combination of cylindrical habitats and solar pa The structure hangs above the Earth in low orbit.
A videophone RINGS OS...
This is Weir.
(tinny) Dr. Weir, Admiral Hollis would like  to see you as soon as possible.

A military office, United States Aerospace Command seal  blazoned on the door. Views of the Earth. Admiral HOLLIS  sits behind his desk, a gruff career officer and a good m Weir enters, escorted by Hollis' adjutant, LYLE.
You wanted to see me, Admiral?
I apologize for the short notice,  Bill, but we've had something come  up that requires your immediate  attention. Lyle?

location: HOLOGRAPHIC DISPLAY OF THE SOLAR SYSTEM

text: Lyle activates a holographic display of the solar system. box magnifies the eighth planet, Neptune, revealing a fla red dot in its orbit.
At oh-three-hundred this morning,  TDRSS picked up an automated  navigation beacon broadcasting at  two minute intervals in Neptune orbit.
Lyle hands Weir a stack of hardcopy data. Weir reads the  data with growing excitement.
Incredible... These are the same  coordinates before the ship  disappeared... this, this happened?  This isn't some kind of hoax?
I wouldn't bring you here on a hoax.  Houston confirms the telemetry and  I.D. codes.
(excited) It's the Event Horizon. She's come  back.
Hollis answers drily.

That ship was lost in deep space,  seven years ago. If the Titanic sailed  into New York harbor, I'd find it  more plausible. (beat) Houston wants Aerospace to send out  a search and rescue team, investigate  the source of the transmission. If  it really is the Event Horizon,  they'll attempt a salvage. (beat) We need you to prepare a detailed  briefing on the ship's systems for  the salvage crew...
A written briefing can't possibly  anticipate the variables on a mission  like this. I have to go with them.
Lyle looks at Weir, stunned by the request.
Dr. Weir, you have no experience  with salvage procedures.

I designed the ship's propulsion  system. I am the only person capable  of evaluating the performance of the  gravity drive. You can't send a Search  and Rescue team out there alone and  expect them to succeed. That would  be like... like sending an auto- mechanic to work on the shuttle.
I can understand your desire to redeem  your reputation, Dr. Weir, but it  doesn't factor into this.

This is not about my reputation!  This is not about me at all! (beat, passionate) The Event Horizon was created for  one reason: to go faster than light.  Imagine mankind exploring new solar  systems, colonizing new worlds. Seven  years ago, we didn't just lose the  ship and the crew. We lost the dream. (beat, quiet and  relentless) I have to go.
It's not that simple. (off of Weir's  expression) Lyle, play the recording for Dr.  Weir.
Navigation Control tried to hail the  vessel. This was the only response.

Lyle presses a button on Hollis' desk. An unholy GARBLE r from office speakers: STATIC and NOISE and INHUMAN VOICES Alone, each sound would raise the hair on your neck. Toge they are unbearable. The sound mercifully cuts off to STATIC. Lyle stops the t Weir sits there, stunned.
Since the initial transmission,  there's been no further contact.  Just the beacon, every two minutes.
The crew? Could they still be alive?
The ship had life support systems  for eighteen months. They're been  gone seven years.
Someone sent that message. Admiral,  you have to put me on that ship.
Hollis stares at Weir, judging the man with his eyes.
It's against my better judgement,  but I'll run this by the Man  downstairs. You'll know my decision  by the end of the day.
Thank you.
Don't thank me, Bill. I'm not doing  you any favors.
Weir leaves. The door closes behind him.
You're not seriously considering  sending him?

You don't just dismiss Bill Weir.  The man held Oppenheimer's chair at  Princeton. If the Event Horizon had  worked, he would have gone down in  history as the greatest mind in  physics since Einstein.
The official inquiry blamed Weir's  design for the ship's loss.
That doesn't mean a damn thing. They  were looking for a scapegoat and  Weir fit the bill. But he's not  responsible for what happened to the  ship.
Does he know that?
What's on your mind?
He doesn't belong on this mission.  Responsible or not, he blames himself.  He's too close to it. (beat) And then there's his wife.
It's been two years since she died.  He's over it.
Some things you don't get over.
Beat.
I want our best people on this.  Where's Miller?
The Lewis and Clark just returned  from patrol in the asteroid belt,  she's docked in bay four.
The Lewis and Clark pulls away from Daylight station, tur towards the depths of space. It is a tough-looking spacec all engine. Sequence omitted from original script.

MOVE IN on thick quartz windows near the ship's nose: the bridge... Split level. Above: avionics, navigation, flight control. STARCK (female, Navigator, sharp mind, sharp tongue) chec the navigation data on her screen as SMITH (male, Pilot,  wrapped too tight) punches in the course.
I can't believe this, I haven't gotten  more than my hand in six weeks and  now this shit. Why not Mars, Cap,  Mars has women...
Smith's right. Neptune? There's  nothing out there. If something  happens, we'll be on our own.
The captain's chair drops from above, swivels to reveal M (male, Captain, intense).
I don't like it either, but you know  the rules: we get the call, we go.  Is the course locked in?
Locked and cocked.
We're past the outer marker, we can  engage the ion drive whenever you're  ready.
Justin?
Below: the bridge's "war-room" -- ship's systems and miss stations. JUSTIN (male, Engineer, young hot-shot).
Everything green on my boards,  Skipper.
Start the countdown.
Ion drive will engage in... T-minus  ten minutes.
Let's go.
Miller slides down a ladder into the war-room. The others follow into...

Bulky EVA (extra-vehicular activity) suits line the walls MUSIC blares from a JAMBOX, built into a storage locker. An Emergency Tech stows safety lines: COOPER -- male, the resident pain-in-the-ass. He SINGS along with the music.
(not breaking stride) Kill it.
Cooper reaches up, turns off the box.
Time to play Spam in the can.
Don't start with me, Cooper.
Cooper falls in as the crew continues into...

Evidence of long term habitation. Personalized lockers. F down bunks, chairs, tables; currently stowed for docking. modular galley. PETERS (female, Emergency Technician, the crew's denmothe and DJ (male, Doctor, a cold perfectionist) load CO2 scru into a bin in the floor. Weir stands to the side like a fifth wheel.
Captain Miller, I just want to say...
The clock is running, Dr. Weir. If  you'll follow the rest of the crew,  they'll show you to the gravity tanks.
Weir hesitates, then follows the crew into Medical. Mille hangs back.
What's the hold up?
Just loading the last of the CO2  scrubbers. (to Miller, accusatory) Good for four months.
I put in for a replacement for you  but no one...
No, no, its alright. I talked to my  ex, he'll keep Denny over Christmas  and I'll get him this summer. (beat) Goddam it, Skipper... I haven't seen  him in two months.
I am sorry. But now we have to go to  work.

A high tech operating room. Modular equipment. Vertical t line the walls, each large enough to hold a human being:  gravity couches. The crew stands before the gravity couches, almost nude, room for modesty. Starck catches Cooper looking at her ass as she strips to her undergarments. Cooper grins. She flips him off, not  bothering to turn around.
Is that an offer?
It is not.
Miller disrobes. Two service tags hang around his neck. H does not remove them. Weir approaches him.
Captain Miller, I appreciate this  opportunity...
Doctor Weir, my crew is not going on  your mission because we want to. We  were pulled off a well deserved leave,  to be sent out to the middle of  nowhere, and no one's even told us  why.
I've been authorized to brief you  and the crew once we reach Neptune  space.
Until then, do what you're told and  stay out of my way.
Weir nods, moves to an empty couch bearing his name, writ on a piece of tape. Peters watches him.
First time in a grav couch?
Yes.
She checks Weir's couch, helps him climb in. Weir keeps o eye on Miller.
(Off of Weir's glance) Don't worry about it. He's hard, but  he's fair. You're lucky to be shipping  out with him. He's one of the few  Captains in the service with  experience in the Outer Reach.
He's been past Mars?
He served on the Goliath.
Wasn't that ship destroyed?

(nods) They attempted to rescue a supply  shuttle bound for Titan. The shuttle's  oh-two tanks ruptured during the  rescue, flooded both ships with pure  oxygen. There was a spark and both  ships were incinerated. The Skipper  and three others just made it to a  lifeboat. Captain Miller was able...
(interrupting) He doesn't like to talk about it.
DJ swathes one of Weir's arms with alcohol.
You didn't eat anything in the past  twelve hours?
Weir shakes his head.
When the Ion drive fires, we'll be  taking about 30 gees. Without a tank,  the force would liquefy your skeleton.
DJ injects Weir. The scientist winces.
I've seen the effect on mice.
The overhead lights change to red.
Five minutes.
DJ hands him the breathing mask.
Put this on.
Weir does. DJ checks the fit.
You'll be fine. You'll wake up and  we'll be there. Watch your fingers.
DJ closes the tank. It begins to fill with green gel. Wei eyes grow large with fear and then the anaesthesia hits. eyes close. His body draws into a fetal position.
(checking the monitor) Heart-rate decreasing... body temp  dropping to 80... 70... 60... 50...  40 degrees Fahrenheit. He's in stasis.
THE ION ENGINE at the aft of the ship begins to glow a de red.
The crew hang inert in the gravity couches.
SILENCE. The engine flares white hot. The Lewis and Clark lances forward.
The Lewis and Clark races SILENTLY past. The engine at it aft holds a sustained fusion reaction like the sun. GRAPHIC: U.S.S. Lewis and Clark. 56 days out.

immobile in the grav tank. He might be sleeping. He might dead. A distant SOUND echoes though the ship, the unholy  garble of human and inhuman voices -- it is the Event Hor calling to him -- the sound refines into a WOMAN'S VOICE, more than a WHISPER:
Billy...
Weir opens his eyes.
I'm so cold...
Weir's grav tank opens.
the seven bodies of the crew, suspended inert in the gel. A sound: DRIP... DRIP... DRIP... Weir slowly walks to the Bridge.
I'm so cold...
A naked WOMAN sits at the helm, her back to us. Completel still. Her skin is very pale. Water pools around her chai Weir stands behind her.
(tentative) Claire?
She does not answer. She does not move. Weir reaches out touch her shoulder, then pulls his hand back, afraid.
Claire? I'm sorry. Claire?
He reaches out again. He touches her hair. She doesn't mo Weir catches her reflection in the computer monitors.  Something wrong with her face... He starts to spin her ar
I'm so cold...
Weir awakes with a jolt, in his grav couch. His mask has  slipped. His tank has filled with blood. He is drowning.

Reality. Weir's eyes open. He presses against the glass o the tank, trying to force it open, panicked. The others a already stepping from open tanks. Weir's tank opens with a HISS. He tumbles to the floor,  gasping, fluid streaming from his mouth. Peters rushes to him.
(gasping) Claire...
DJ! (to Weir) It's okay. You're okay. Just breathe.
Weir catches his breath. He looks up. The crew surrounds  him, concerned.
I'm alright now. I'm alright...
DJ helps him to his feet.
Move slowly. You've been in stasis  for fifty-six days. You're going to  experience a little disorientation.
Weir nods.
Damn, Dr. Weir, don't scare us like  that. Coffee?
What?
Coffee.
No, thank you.
Cooper, still butt-naked and proud of it, grabs a metal  cylinder from the wall and pours a mug for himself.
Hey, Starck. You wanna dry my back?
Starck gives him a cool once over.
Maybe when you finish puberty.
Miller zips up.
Starck, why aren't you on the bridge?
I just finished drying...
Then what are you doing here? Come  on, people, let's go! (to Cooper) And Cooper... Put some pants on.
SILENCE. The Lewis and Clark drifts towards Neptune.

The crew has secured the quarters from flight status. Bun have been folded down, each alcove personalized with  photographs and pin-ups. DJ moves around the cabin, checking the crew's radiation  badges. Cooper and Justin sit on their bunks, tossing a handball  across the cabin. Peters holds a "Watchman" video unit, watching a "video  letter"...
...from DENNY, her four-year-old son, a paraplegic, grinn widely in his new wheelchair:
(video) Play horsey, Mommy, play horsey...
IN THE VIDEO, Peters enters shot, scoops her child from t chair.
(video) Want to play horsey, do you... (etc.)
Weir sits huddled in a blanket. Miller takes a seat next him. Starck and Smith enter. Starck sits next to Miller.
30 hours to Neptune orbit.
All boards are green, everything's  five by five.
That's good to know. Justin, you  wanna stow that?
Justin catches the ball, holds onto it.
Okay, listen up. As you all know by  now, we have an addition to our crew.  Dr. Weir, this is: Starck, navigation;  Smith, pilot, Justin, ship's engineer --
You can call him Baby-bear, he loves  that...
This is Cooper, what the hell do you  do on this ship, anyway?
Ballast.
(to Weir) I am your best friend. I am a  lifesaver and a heartbreaker...
He's a rescue technician. Peters,  medical technician. DJ...
Trauma.
And this is mission specialist Dr.  William Weir. We all know where we're  going. Dr. Weir is going to tell us  why.
Miller and the crew look at Weir, waiting. Weir clears hi throat.
What I am about to tell you is  considered code-black by the NSA.
The crew look at each other: they haven't heard that in a mission briefing before.
That means top-secret, Cooper.
I heard it.
The USAC intercepted a radio  transmission from a decaying orbit  around Neptune. The source has been  identified as the Event Horizon.
STUNNED SILENCE. Then everyone talks at once:
That's impossible! She was lost with  all hands, what, seven...
Seven years ago, the reactor blew...
How can we salvage...?
Let the dead rest, man...
...cancel our leave and send us out  on some bullshit mission...!
EVERYBODY SHUT UP! Let the man speak.
In the quiet that follows:

What was made public about the Event  Horizon, that she was a deep space  research vessel, that its reactor  went critical, that the ship blew  up... None of that is true. (beat) The Event Horizon was the culmination  of a secret government project to  create a spacecraft capable of faster- than-light flight.
The crew stares at Weir: he has just dropped another bomb them.
You can't do that.
The law of relativity prohibits faster- than-light travel...

Relativity, yes. We can't break the  law of relativity, but we can go  around it. The ship doesn't really  move faster than the speed of light;  it creates a dimensional gateway  that allows the ship to  instantaneously "jump" from one point  in the universe to another, light  years away.
How?

Well, in layman's terms, you use a  rotating magnetic field to focus a  narrow beam of gravitons; these in  turn fold space-time consistent with  Weyl tensor dynamics until the space- time curvature becomes infinitely  large and you have a singularity...
Laymen's terms.
Weir thinks of another way to explain it. He rips a pin-u from Smith's locker.
Hey...

Say this paper represents space-time,  and you want to get from "point A"  here... (marks it on the photo  with a pen) ...to "point B," here. (marks point B) Now: what's the shortest distance  between two points?
The crew stares at him. Starck decides to play.
A straight line.
Wrong. The shortest distance between  two points...
Weir folds the paper, lining up point A over point B... t THRUSTING his pen through both, skewering the pin-up.

...is zero. That's what the  singularity does: it folds space, so  that point A and point B coexist in  the same space and time. After the  ship passes through this gateway,  space returns to normal. (hands the ruined pin- up back to Smith) It's called a gravity drive.
How do you know all this?
I built it.
Even Cooper is impressed.
I can see why they sent you along.
So if the ship didn't blow up, what  happened?

It was the ship's maiden voyage, to  test the drive. The Event Horizon  moved to safe distance using ion  thrusters. They received the go-ahead  to activate the gravity drive. (beat) And the ship vanished from all our  scopes. No radar contact, no enhanced  optical, no radio contact of any  kind. They disappeared without a  trace. (beat) Until now.
Where has it been for the last seven  years?
That's what we're here to find out.
The Lewis and Clark flashes silently past, heading deeper and deeper into space.
The crew assembled.
We haven't been able to confirm any  live contact, but TDRSS did receive  a single transmission from the Event  Horizon.

Weir punches a button on a console. The transmission BLAR from the bridge's speakers, STATIC and NOISE and, underne all, INHUMAN VOICES. The crew listen, look at one another. The recording ends  abruptly.
What the hell is that?
It doesn't sound like anything human.
Houston has passed the recording  through several filters and isolated  what appears to be a human voice.
He activates a different file. The resulting WAIL is more human but no less terrifying, a cry of despair. The last  message from a drowning man...
Jesus...
What is that?
It sounds like Latin.
Latin? Who the fuck speaks Latin?
No one. It's a dead language.
Mostly dead.
What does it say?
NSA encryption specialists have  deciphered some of the message...
Weir plays the HELLISH INCANTATION for a third time.
There: "...liberatis me..." They  haven't been able to translate the  rest, it's too distorted.
"Liberatis me." "Save me."
From what?
(to Weir) You're convinced the crew could still  be alive? After seven years?
The Event Horizon only had life  support for eighteen months. It seems  impossible, but in light of the  transmission... I have to think that  someone has managed to endure until  now.
Skipper, do we get hazard pay for  this?
You heard the tape, Smith. We're  looking for survivors.
The Lewis and Clark closes in on the blue planet.
The flight crew assembled. Data flashes across the main  monitors on the bridge.
Crossing the horizon. Optimum approach  angle is fourteen degrees.
Come around to three-three-four...
(echoing) Heading three-three-four...
(continuing) ...Make your approach vector negative  fourteen degrees...
One-four degrees...
RCS thrusters pivot and fire as the ship enters Neptune o dropping lower and lower into the dense blue clouds...
The ship begins to rock as it encounters atmosphere, a gr vibration. GRAPHICS flash across the main window's HUD. Neptune's da shadow fills the screen.
We have a lock on the Event Horizon's  navigation beacon. It's in the upper  ionosphere, we're in for some chop.
Bring us in tight. Starck, get on  the horn, see if anyone's listening...
(into radio) This is U.S. Aerospace Command vessel  Lewis and Clark, hailing Event  Horizon, Event Horizon, do you  read...? This is the Lewis and Clark,  hailing... (she continues B.G.)
(over Starck) Matching speed... now. Range to target  ten thousand meters and closing...  Skipper, I got a bad feeling about  this...
We're all on edge, Smith. We're a  long way out...
That's not it. That ship was built  to go faster than light... That's  just wrong, it goes against everything  we know...
What are you trying to say? "If God  had intended Man to fly, he would  have given us wings?"
Something like that, yeah.
Miller grins grimly.
I guess we're about to find out.  Keep us slow and steady.
Yes, sir.
Dr. Weir...!
Weir sticks his head into the bridge.
I think you want to see this.
Weir climbs up the ladder to the flight deck.
Where is she?
Dead ahead, 5000 meters.
Suddenly, the ship SHUDDERS VIOLENTLY. Weir braces himself in the doorway, staring out the forwa window into the roiling azure clouds. Smith grimaces, his knuckles white at the controls.
We've got some weather.
I noticed. Starck, anybody home?
If they are, they're screening their  calls.
Range 3000 meters and closing.
I can't see anything...
Only turbid clouds of methane ice whirl past the Lewis an Clark's windows.
1500 meters. We're getting too  close...
Where is it?
(checking her console) The scope is lit, it's right in front  of us...
1000 meters...
A red warning light begins to flash in time with a shrill BEEP.
Proximity warning! 900, 800 meters,  700... we're right on top of it,  we're gonna hit!
Starck...
It should be right there...
She looks up, trails off...
My God.

...the clouds break, revealing... THE EVENT HORIZON, right in front of them. A black  labyrinthine blasphemy against Neptune's arctic blue. Clo banks encircle the ship as if it were the eye of a hurric
Reverse thrusters full!
The Event Horizon looms enormous as the Lewis and Clark h off the port stern, dwarfed by the giant ship.
The turbulence subsides. The bridge crew stares at the ma craft. The only sound, the PROXIMITY WARNING. Finally:
Jesus, that is one big ugly fat  fucker...
She's not ugly.
Miller reaches over Smith's shoulder, turns off the proxi warning. Smith snaps back to business.
Range 500 meters and holding.  Turbulence is dropping off...
Picking up magnetic interference.
Put it through TACS. Smith, you up  for a flyby?
(he is not) Love to.
The Lewis and Clark maneuvers in close to the Event Horiz dwarfed by the dark ship.
Smith keeps a tight hand on the controls. The crew stare the viewport at the abandoned craft.
Look at the size of that thing.
Weir explains the view out the cockpit window.

Foredecks. Crew quarters, bridge,  medical and science labs, hydroponics,  what have you. That central section  connects the forward decks to the  Engineering containment area. Can we  move in closer?
Shit, Doc, any closer and we're gonna  need a rubber...
Do it.
Smith grimaces. His hands move carefully over the control
The Lewis and Clark moves even closer. Vanishing into the shadow of the Event Horizon.
The crew stares at the ship rushing past the viewport. A  huge spherical structure looms eerily ahead.
That's the engineering containment.  And there's the main airlock. We can  dock there.
Smith, use the arm and lock us onto  that antennae cluster.
Be careful. It's not a load bearing  structure...

The Lewis and Clark carefully maneuvers in close to the E Horizon's airlock. A mechanical boom-arm extends from the smaller ship to la onto the Event Horizon. Its clawed hand grabs the antenna cluster. The cluster buckles under the stress.
(to Weir) It is now. (to Miller) We're locked in.
Starck, give me a read.
A scan of the Event Horizon appears across Starck's scree
The reactor's still hot. We've got  several small radiation sources,  leaks probably. Nothing serious.
Do they have pressure?
Affirmative. The hull's intact...  but there's no gravity and the thermal  units are off line. I'm showing deep  cold. The crew couldn't survive unless  they were in stasis.
Find 'em, Starck.
Starck frowns at her display.
Something's wrong with the bio-scan.
Radiation interference?
There's not enough radiation to throw  off the scan. I'm picking up trace  life forms, but I can't get a lock  on the location.
Could it be the crew? If they were  in suspended animation, wouldn't  that effect the scan?
If they were in stasis, I'd get a  location, but these readings, they're  all over the ship. It doesn't make  any sense.
Okay. We do it the hard way. Deck by  deck, room by room. Starck, deploy  the umbilicus. I believe you're up  for a walk, Mr. Justin. Go get your  bonnet on.
Yes, sir!
Weir starts to follow Justin from the bridge.
Dr. Weir, I need you on the bridge.
Captain, I didn't come out here to  sit on your bridge, I need to be on  that ship...
Once the ship is secured, we'll bring  you on board --
(interrupting) That is not acceptable --
(overlapping) -- once we've secured the ship, that's  the way it is! (beat) I need you to guide us from the comm  station. This is where I need you.  Help us to do our job.
Weir exhales.
Very well.
The docking collar umbilicus extends to the Event Horizon airlock.
Miller, Peters, Justin and Cooper in EVA; Cooper and Just without headgear.
...come on, Skipper, I already put  my shoes on...
(muffled) You've had plenty EVA, Coop, it's  Justin's turn. Stay on station. If  anything happens...
I'll be all over it.
Miller nods to Peters.
(muffled) Opening inner airlock door.
The inner airlock door opens: CH-THUNK. Miller, Peters an Justin enter the airlock. Justin attaches his safety line Miller and Peters do not.
You still need the rope? I thought  you were one a those spacemen with  ice in ya veins.
I'd rather be on the rope and not  need it than need it and not have  it. Now step aside, old man.
Cooper puts Justin's helmet on. It seals tight.
(serious now) You just keep your nose clean, Baby  Bear. Clear the door.
Cooper backs out, allowing the inner airlock door to shut ECHOING through the ship.

Miller, Peters and Justin float down the brightly lit  umbilicus into the Event Horizon, all in EVA suits. Justi safety line trails out behind him. The OUTER AIRLOCK DOOR of the Event Horizon waits for the
Weir has taken over Justin's station. He watches the POV  monitors like a kid watching Christmas. Smith and Starck  keep tabs over his shoulder.
You've reached the outer airlock  door.
Peters attaches a thumper -- a device using sound waves t measure pressure -- to the inner airlock door.
We've got pressure.
Clear and open on my mark. Three...  two... one... mark.
Peters inserts a zero-G drill into the panel beside the d The door slowly opens...

The immense corridor stretches away into darkness in both directions. Distantly spaced windows manifest as remote p of blue light amidst endless black, adding to the vast se of scale. The light from their dual spotlights on the team's helmet reflects off tiny ice crystals of frozen atmosphere. They are ants in a tomb built for giants.
Jesus its huge.
Ice crystals everywhere. This place  is a deep freeze.
(radio) You're in the central corridor. It  connects the personnel areas to  Engineering.
Peters and I will search the forward  decks. Justin, take Engineering. No  hot-dogging, not on this one, alright?
Not a chance, sir.
The group separates. Justin kicks off from the wall, shoo down the corridor at immense speed.

Miller and Peters move in the opposite direction. They us magnetic plates on their boots and gloves to cling to the walls as they slowly make their way down the dark shaft.  Their journey seems endless. The darkness almost seems a  living thing as it surrounds them.
Miller spots something at a coupling, where two sections the corridor join...
Dr. Weir, what's this?
Miller indicates a box nestled against the coupling. The  universal symbol for explosives is on the cover.
(ahead at the next  coupling) Here's another one. They're all over  the place.
(radio) They're explosive charges.
I can see that, what're they for?

In an emergency, the charges detonate  in series, destroying the central  section and separating the personnel  areas from the rest of the ship.  That way, if the gravity drive  malfunctions, the crew could use the  foredecks as a lifeboat.
Peters and Miller keep moving.
That means they didn't abandon ship.
So where are they? Starck, any luck  with the bio-scan?
I'm running diagnostics now,  Skipper... Nothing's wrong with the  sensor pack, I'm still getting trace  life readings, all over the ship.
Miller and Peters unconsciously look around. Sweat beads  their faces.
There's no one in the corridor but  us.
(radio) Not according to the computer.
Peters is right, no one's here.
I don't know, this place is really  dark, I can't see a thing...
She starts to wave her searchlight around wildly.
(calming her down) Easy, Peters, we're okay, we're okay.  Let's finish the sweep.
(radio) Captain Miller, the foredecks are  just ahead.
I can see the hatch.
Starck, you still showing those  readings?
(radio) That's an affirmative.
(to Peters) Keep your eyes open.
She nods as he reaches for the hatch...

The hatch opens, allowing Peters and Miller entrance into the forward decks. These areas were intended for human  habitation, and seem similar in design to the Lewis and C only larger. Gravity couches line both walls, eighteen in all. Empty.
We found the gravity couches.
Weir peers eagerly at the monitors.
Any survivors?
(radio) Negative.
Hope drains from Weir's face.
No one?
They're empty, Dr. Weir. Moving  forward.
Miller and Peters split up, each taking a separate exit f the chamber.
Weir looks at Justin's POV screen: a grainy image of the  First Containment Seal.
Justin stands before a thick pressure door. Justin checks the door with his thumper, his boots are now on.
(radio) You've reached the First Containment  Seal. The engineering decks are on  the other side.
We still have pressure. The radiation  count's steady at 7 millirads an  hour.
(radio) Background radiation. Perfectly safe.
Justin touches a panel beside the door. It opens. He ente
...a long corridor shaped like a tube. It rotates like a  turbine, causing vertigo. Justin's BREATH echoes in his h as he moves forward...
Cooper stares at Justin's safety line in the airlock.
counts off silently, passing 150 meters...
The corridor ends at a pressure door.
Dr. Weir, what's this the door to?
(radio) You're at the Bridge, Ms. Peters.  You still haven't seen any crew?

Miller, moving through a deserted lab. Empty operating ta Stainless steel surgical instruments float in zero-G. A g floats up behind him, brushes his shoulder. He wheels... glove is empty. It spins away.
If we saw any crew, Doctor, you'd  know about it. (looking around) I'm in Medical. No casualties, it  looks like this place has never been  used.
He finds a computer console.
Peters opens the door.
Peters enters. Looks around: a small antechamber for crew briefings, with chairs and a display table. Red crystals  float in a crimson mist around her.
I found something.
Weir peers at the monitors, trying to make out the red ha
Yes, we can see some kind of mist.  What is that?
(radio) Blood. Looks like arterial spray.
(nervous) Can you see a body?
(confused) There's no one here.
(radio) The blood came from somewhere,  Peters...
There's no one here, Skipper.
Peters takes a sample container from her belt. Carefully  tries to capture a suspended crystal...
Come on...
and the Container; Peters' brow furrowed with concentrati

head_text.subj: ...THE WALL BEHIND PETERS, CASED IN A FROZEN EXPLOSION OF

text: BLOOD AND TISSUE. Someone died here in a violent and terr way. Peters starts to look up but the flash dies away. She nev saw the horror behind her. Peters turns her attention back to her tiny crystal. She  traps the it, returns the container to her belt. She moves from the antechamber into...
Her helmet lights sweep the room. Every surface a control panel.
Okay. I'm on the bridge.
(radio) What you got, Peters?
Peters examines the other consoles -- most are dark but f a few dim lights.
Everything's been shut down.  Conserving power, I guess. Green  light on the hull, it's intact.
The science workstation has power,  I'll see if I can find the crew from  here.
Weir stares at Peters' monitor.
Ms. Peters, turn back and to your  left, please.
On her monitor, Peters' POV shifts as she complies.
What is it?
Ship's log.
(radio) I see it.
Peters reaches towards a small video deck. Touches the ej button. Nothing happens.
It's stuck.
Justin's light bounces off an even larger pressure door,  built like a bank vault. The Second Seal.
I've reached another containment  door. This thing's huge...
(radio) That's the Second Containment Seal.  Beyond that, engineering.
I'm going in.
Justin opens the seal. It releases SLOWLY, inching open.  Justin squeezes through.
Peters takes a small probe from her belt, inserts it into the video deck. A small laser disc emerges partway from the deck. Peters  pulls on it. It doesn't move.
It's really jammed in there.

A shadow crosses the window behind her. Someone -- someth is in there with her... Peters pulls harder. Nothing. Another effort. The disc pu free. Peters spins in the zero-gravity, spinning into... ...A BODY floating at the helm, the face illuminated by  Peters' helmet lights. His swollen tongue clogs his gapin screaming mouth. His cracked and crystallized skin is cro by a network of bloated veins. He has no eyes. Just like  Weir's dream.
Peters' monitor shows the CORPSE'S face, its mouth open i mute agony. Weir GASPS.
Peters pushes free of the body.
(professional) I found one.
(radio) Alive?
Frozen.
The dead man's face leers from Peters' monitor.
What happened to his eyes?
Explosive decompression.
Decompression wouldn't do that.
Weir just stares at the ruined face, rapt. Starck notices
You okay?
Weir nods, not taking his eyes from the screen.
Cooper, on station. He keys his radio.
Hey, Baby Bear, Mama Bear got a  corpsicle for ya...
No reply.
Miller looks up from the workstation, concerned.
(radio) Baby Bear, you copy?
Cooper stares out at Justin's safety line slowly counting off past 175 meters.
Justin, do you copy?
The Second Seal is open. Justin's safety line snakes into darkness. FOLLOW the safety line into the dark...

An alcove, opening into a vast chamber. Once pristine, al the surfaces have been coated in a dark gray slick. Globu of fluid hang motionless, sticking to Justin's suit, leec away his light and swallowing him in darkness.
(radio) ...do you copy?
(quiet) Uh, yeah Coop, I'm still here.
(radio) Shit! Do not do that! Where the fuck  are you?
I'm in the Second Containment area.  It's pitch black in here. There must  have been a coolant leak. Man, this  shit is everywhere. I can't see a  damn thing.
A lighted console blocks Justin's view of the chamber bey He drifts over to it, wipes the console clear of coolant, revealing dim lights: the station has power.
The reactor's still hot. Coolant  level is on reserve, but still in  the green.

head_text.subj: TIGHT ON JUSTIN'S FACE AS THE LIGHTS COME ON

text: (triumph) I got it...
His expressions changes as he looks past the console and  sees... something.
(trailing off in awe) Holy shit...
Justin?
I think I found something...

A massive sphere, 10 meters in diameter, dominates the ce of the second containment. Intricate machinery surrounds sphere but the globe itself is featureless, smooth; a  enigmatic monolith. Black ice encrusts it, giving it the  seeming of a living thing.
They stare at Justin's monitor.
What the hell is that?
That's the Core: the gravity drive.  The heart of the ship.
(radio) Justin, check the containment for  radiation leaks. Peters...
(radio) ...how's the client?
Crystallized.
Justin examines the outer wall of the Core, looking for a cracks or ruptured seams.
(radio) Justin, finish your sweep.
Almost done, I just gotta check one  thing...
Justin turns to the Core...
Justin's monitor fills with static.
Justin, hold on a sec, you're breaking  up...
(radio) Justin...? (static obscure her  voice)
Justin reaches towards the Core with his pressure sensor. His helmet light flickers. He hesitates...
Miller's helmet light flickers...
Peter's helmet light winks out...
Justin, come in...
Suddenly, the bio-scan lights up, from green to red as si race across the display.
What is it?
I don't know. The life readings just  went off the scale.
Something's wrong...

Justin places the pressure sensor against the Core. Touch it. The Core turns deepest black. A darkness that light canno penetrate. For a second, Justin's white suit is captured  against the hungry void...

head_text.subj: THEN THE VOID SUCKS HIM IN AND JUSTIN IS GONE...

text: Cooper stares in shock as Justin's safety line as it reel out at an incredible rate -- 250 meters, 300 meters...
surges out of the Core, bending light like a ripple on a  pond, pushing coolant and debris before it...
The gravity wave surges forward, blowing out emergency li as it comes, flotsam and jetsam swirling in its wake...
Data floods Miller's workstation, flashing across the scr too fast for comprehension...
What the hell...
A DEEP ROAR fills the ship. Miller rises to investigate.. The door BLOWS APART as THE WAVE HITS, ripples through th Medical Bay towards Miller...
Oh shit...!
Debris swirls around him... the wave sweeps him up... SLA him into a bulkhead...

the briefest suggestion of a SCREAMING FACE, obscured by  STATIC and ROLL before the screen CUTS to static entirely The rest of the crew's POV screens go dead as... ...the wave hits them, threatening to tear the Lewis and  Clark apart. The ship shudders violently. Consoles EXPLOD with sparks. Weir and the others hold on for dear life.
Miller, do you read me, Peters --
Get them back --
I'm trying, goddammit --
An equipment rack IGNITES. Smith grabs an extinguisher, f the blaze...
Cooper and DJ, bracing against the bulkhead. Cooper hits intercom.
What's happening?
(intercom) I don't know, the screens are dead...!
Cooper peers out the airlock window.
passes 350 meters and accelerating...
350 meters... 400 meters...
He's in trouble. Go!
I'm gone!

Cooper grabs his helmet. DJ helps him lock the helmet int place with a HISS. The inner airlock door opens. As Cooper enters the airloc Justin's safety reel stops, the line jerking taut at 500  meters.
Miller tries to get his bearings in the dark.
Boarding party, sound off... Peters,  do you read me... . Peters...

Peters' light, too, remains dark, but Neptune's blue ligh fills the Bridge. The frozen corpse floats before her. No longer a man. A young boy, maybe five years old. His legs are withered, useless things. The skin remains a crystallized surface, the eyes look straight at her, alive.
Denny...
Peters reaches out to touch the body. It falls away from  her. No longer her son, but the body of the astronaut. It hits the door and shatters.
(growing desperation) ...Peters, do you read me...
A MAN'S VOICE, in agony, CRACKLES over Miller's radio:
(radio) Don't leave me...
Justin? Justin, sound off...  Justin...!
Miller trails off as RED LIGHT flickers across his visor. turns...

A BURNING MAN stands in Medical/Science, a human body wre in flame. The eyes are like sunspots. As the Burning Man  moves, bones and black flesh poke through the fire. He ra one hand to point at Miller in accusation...
Miller's BREATH stops in his throat. His mouth works but  nothing comes out. He BLINKS... ...and the VISION is gone. Miller is alone, BREATHING har
Cooper enters at full speed, shooting through in a contro fall...
Hold on, Baby Bear...
...into the Second Containment. He catches himself at the console. Cooper sees Justin's safety line, cut off abrupt by the darkness of the Core.
Oh my God...

The darkness of the Core ripples... Justin suddenly emerges from the darkness, a white figure riding a wave of impenetrable blackness. Cooper catches him, holds him tight as the wave carries t towards the wall. Cooper sees a control rod -- a long met spike -- coming at them. He twists his body so that they  miss -- barely -- before slamming into the wall.
Justin, do you read me? Justin... .
Cooper pulls Justin close. Justin's head lolls to one sid Unconscious.
Baby Bear, don't do this. Don't do  this...
Weir, Starck and Smith continue to hold on tightly as the vibration builds... and builds...
Here comes another one! Hold on!

The second wave hits. Sparks fly as consoles EXPLODE. Dee in the ship metal SCREAMS, followed by the SHRIEK of esca atmosphere. An emergency klaxon RINGS out: PRESSURE WARNI Starck checks Justin's station:
We lost the starboard baffle! The  hull's been breached!
The Bridge pressure door begins to close...and then stop.
The safety circuit's failed!
We're losing atmosphere...
There are pressure suits in the  Airlock. Go!
Starck pushes Weir ahead of her, Smith follows hard as th run the length of the ship for the airlock bay.
The vibration subsides.
Can anybody hear me...
(radio) Skipper...
Peters...
(radio) ...you okay?
Yeah. I'm -- I'm okay.
Her voice cracks as she says it. She looks anything but.
The reports come, one on the other...
(radio) We have a man down...
Coop, where are you...
(radio) The containment, Second Containment...
Hold on, Coop...
(radio) Captain Miller...
Smith, where the hell have you been?!
We have a situation here...
Starck and Smith already in suits. DJ assists Weir. Smith has already locked his helmet into place.
(continuing) We lost the starboard baffle and the  hull cracked. Our safety seals didn't  close, the circuit's fried --
Miller moves down the central corridor towards his wounde ship.
Do we have enough time for a weld?
(radio) We don't have time to fart.
We're losing pressure at 280 liters  a second and our oxygen tanks are  cracked. In three minutes, our  atmosphere will be gone. We are  fucking dead.
No one's dying on my watch, Smith!  What about the reserve tanks?
(radio) They're gone.
Beat. Miller closes his eyes, desperately trying to think a solution.
PAN across the faces of the astronauts. No hope. Except f Weir:
The Event Horizon.
The others turn to stare at Weir.
What?
It still has air and reserve power,  we can activate gravity and life  support.
What if the air has gone bad? We  can't wear these suits forever.
I don't think this is a good idea,  we don't even know what happened on  that ship...
It beats dying, Mister Smith.
Dr. Weir's right. Get on board the  Event Horizon. I'll meet you at the  airlock.
(radio) But...
You heard me, Smith. Peters, are you  with me?
Peters at the life support console.
I'm ahead of you. Bringing the thermal  units on line...
Peters flips a series of circuit-breakers. Reaches for th final switch.
Hold tight and prep for gees.
Everything floating in the bridge CRASHES to the floor.
Justin and Cooper collapse to the deck, coolant splashing down all around them...
Miller meets the crew as they evacuate the Lewis and Clar Weir leads the way, eager; Smith hangs back.
Everybody okay?
We're all here.
Okay. Let's find out how much time  we just bought.
Miller reaches for the catch on his own helmet.
We haven't tested the air yet. It  could be contaminated...
No time. We need whatever's left in  our suits to repair the Clark. Like  it or not, this is the only oxygen  for three billion kilometers.
Miller pulls his helmet off with a HISS. He breathes deep Starck does the same, coughs.
It tastes bad.
But you can breathe it.

The Lewis and Clark and the Event Horizon, locked togethe in Neptune orbit. Lights shine from the Horizon as power restored. No longer cloaked in darkness, it is revealed i all its hideous glory, a nightmare etched in steel.
Weir moves from station to station, restoring power to ea Starck sits at the communications workstation. Miller wat over her shoulder.
The antennae array's completely fried,  we've got no radio, no laser, no  highgain... No one's going to be  coming to help us.
How much oh-two do we have?
Oxygen is not the problem.
Carbon dioxide?
(nods) It's building up with every breath  we take. And the CO2 filters on the  Event Horizon are shot.
We can take the filters from the  Clark...
I thought of that, with the filters  from the Clark, we've got enough  breathable air for twenty hours.  After that, we'd better be on our  way home.
What about the life readings you  picked up?

The Event Horizon sensors show the  same thing: "Bio-readings of  indeterminate origin." Right before  that wave hit the Clark, there was  some kind of surge, right off the  scale, but now it's back to its  previous levels.
What's causing the readings?
I don't know, but whatever it is,  it's not the crew.
So where is the rest of the crew?  We've been over every inch of this  ship and all we've found is blood.  Dr. Weir? Any suggestions?
Weir just stares at the bloodstained wall.
What happened here?
Miller follows Weir's gaze to the wall: a Rorschach test blood...
PULL BACK from the bridge windows TO REVEAL...

...the Event Horizon in all its horrific glory, hanging s in the center of the hurricane like a mote in God's eye. The Lewis and Clark clings to the giant craft, as  insignificant as a tick. An even smaller figure clings to the hull of the Lewis and Clark...

It's Smith, EVA in full protective gear. His magnetic boo hold him to the Lewis and Clark's hull. He kneels over a  hole in the hull, where the metal has buckled and torn. V still leaks from the hole into space.
Captain Miller, you copy?
(radio) I'm here, Smith, how's the Clark?
I've found a six inch fracture in  the outer hull. We should be able to  repair it and re-pressurize, it's  gonna take some time.
(radio) We don't have time, Smith. In twenty  hours we run out of air.
Understood.
Smith uses a foam applicator to fill the hole. The gel fr in place. Smith reaches to his belt, pulls out a ZERO-G  NAILGUN. Presses it to the patch and begins to rivet it i place.

Justin lies unmoving on a table. His eyes are open, stari at a smear of blood on the ceiling. A needle slides into the skin below his eye. He doesn't  respond. DJ removes the needle. It glistens with blood. He looks u at Miller and Peters.
How is he?
His vitals are stable, but he's  unresponsive to stimuli. He might  wake up in fifteen minutes. He might  not wake up at all.
What happened to him?
DJ shakes his head. Miller eyes the bloodstain above them
DJ, take samples from these stains,  compare them to medical records, I  want to know whose blood this is.

Gravity has scattered debris and freeze-dried blood about the room. The crew (Justin and Smith excepted) tries to r on the chairs of dead men. Their faces are wan and haggar Weir relaxes at the table. Unlike the others, he seems al at ease. DJ remains forever stoic; Starck, animated and  nervous. Cooper bounces the handball on the floor, a refl action. Miller stares at a video monitor, watching Smith repair t Lewis and Clark. He turns from the window.

Okay, people, there's been a change  in the mission. In less than eighteen  hours, we will run out of breathable  air. Our primary objective is now  survival. That means we focus on  repairing the Lewis and Clark and  salvaging whatever will buy us more  time. (pause) Our secondary objective is finding  out what happened to this ship and  its crew. Two months from now, I  fully intend to be standing in front  of the good Admiral giving my report,  and I'd like to have more than my  dick in my hands.
Grim smiles all around.
Peters, I want you to go through the  ship's log, see if we can't find  some answers.
I can use the station in Medical,  keep an eye on Justin...
Fine. Starck, I want you to repeat  the bio-scan...
What's the point? I'll just get the  same thing...
Not acceptable. I want to know what's  causing those readings. If the crew  is dead, I want the bodies, I want  the crew found.
I can reconfigure the scan for C-12,  amylase proteins.
Do it. Dr. Weir...
Yes.
One of my men is down. I want to  know what happened to him.
I told you. He was inside the Core...
Weir starts shaking his head.
It was like... nothing was there...  and then Justin appeared and the  Core... became metal...
(cutting him off) No, he didn't.
You weren't there. I saw it.
Saw what, Mr. Cooper? What did you  really see, because what you're  describing is not physically  possible...
Cooper throws the ball at him, hard. Weir ducks. It bounc wildly around the room. Miller catches it.
Cooper! Enough!
Cooper sits down.
(turning on Weir) Dr. Weir, Justin may die. Whatever  happened to him could happen to all  of us.
Beat.
I don't know what happened to Justin.
I'm telling you, I saw it...
What you saw could have been an  optical effect caused by gravitational  distortion.
(turning on Weir) I know what I saw and it wasn't a  fucking "optical effect!"
Hold on, what's this "gravitational  distortion?"
It's possible that a burst of gravity  waves escaped from the Core,  distorting space-time. They could be  what hit the Lewis and Clark.
What could cause them? (Weir doesn't answer) What's in the Core?
It's complicated...
How much time do you need? We have  seventeen hours and forty-two minutes.  Now: what is in the Core?
Beat. Here comes another bomb...
A black hole.
The crew stares at him, stunned.

Miller, Starck and Weir stand before the Core. Dark omino structures loom around them, glistening with coolant. The PULSE of the ship is loud here, a deep THRUM that steals  their breath. Weir's voice is a reverent WHISPER:
That's how the gravity drive works,  you see: it focuses the black hole's  immense gravitational power to create  the gateway. That's how the Event  Horizon travels faster than light.
I can't believe we built this.
It's insane.
"Insane?" The finest astronauts fought  to be posted to this ship. It would  take the Lewis and Clark a thousand  years to reach our closest star. The  Event Horizon could be there in a  day...
If it worked.
If it worked, yes.
They stare at the Core, the surrounding machinery moving a slow giant's dance. A trick of the eye, or does the Cor stare back at them?
I want this room sealed. The Second  Containment is off limits.
There's no danger. The black hole is  contained behind three magnetic  fields, it's under control.
Your black hole damn near ripped my  ship apart. It may have killed one  of my men. (beat) No one goes near that thing.
until its darkness fills the screen...

Peters sits before the computer workstation, running the  ship's log, forwarding through hours of boring footage. R her eyes. The lights flicker. Peters hears something RUSTLING behind her. She turns...
Justin...?

Justin lies unmoving on the nearest examination table.  Comatose. Peters reaches out and picks up a scalpel. Peters hears the sound again, FINGERNAILS ON PLASTIC. She moves past Justin... ...past several empty tables, covered with clear plastic. ...to the last table. She stares in shock.

head_text.subj: THERE'S SOMETHING UNDERNEATH THE PLASTIC COVER

text: She slowly reaches out. Lifts the cover. Her son DENNY looks at her and GIGGLES. She GASPS. The sc drops to the floor at her feet. Denny reaches up to her, to be picked up...
Mommy...
...but the plastic that still covers his withered legs sq like a bag full of snakes... Peters drops the plastic and backs away.
Peters?
She turns. DJ stands in the doorway, holding blood sample Peters turns back, but her son is gone. DJ reads her expression.
What's wrong?
Nothing. It's nothing.

The Airlock light turns red -- a warning. The Inner Airlo door control flashes: "LOCKED." The Outer Airlock door op Smith enters. He closes the Outer Airlock door. Atmospher HISSES into the chamber. The Inner Airlock door flashes:
Cooper in EVA, getting ready to go outside. The Inner Air door opens. Smith enters. Takes off his helmet.
You been out there a long time. Trying  to break my record?
I'd rather spend the next twelve  hours Outside than another five  minutes in this can. This ship is  bad. It watches you.
What?
You heard me. This ship, it's crazy:  trying to go faster'n light, that's  like the Tower of Babel.
Shit, Smith, you're going Biblical  on me.
You know what happened to the Tower  of Babel, don't you? It fell down.
You're sucking too much nitrogen in  your mix.
Starck programs the sensor workstation. She glances over Weir: sitting at a computer terminal, his face rapt as da flashes by. His lips move, muttering to himself.
Why Dr. Weir, I think you're in love.
Hmmm. Claire used to tell me I loved  the Event Horizon more than I loved  her. I told her that wasn't true, I  just knew the Event Horizon better,  that's all.
Claire is your wife?
Yes.
It must be hard, being so far away  from her.
Yes. I miss her. She died. Two years  now.
I'm sorry.
Weir keeps his attention focused on the screen.
These things happen. (reacting to something  on the screen) Wait a minute, that's not right...
He fingers fly across the keyboard, double-checking the d Miller leans over Weir's shoulder.
You have something, Dr. Weir?
The date.
What about it?
The Event Horizon's computer think's  it's 2034.
Exactly. The ship's internal clock  is off by seven years.
Maybe a power interruption crashed  the system...
No, there's no evidence of a surge  or spike of any kind. It's as if  time just... stopped for seven years.
Explanation?

Intense gravitational fields effect  the passage of time, it's possible... (beat) Black holes make sense on paper,  it's all math, you see, but as to  what really happened... (he shakes his head) The Event Horizon has passed beyond  our plane of reality, and like  Lazarus, returned from the dead.
The INTERCOM interrupts them:
(intercom) Captain Miller, Dr. Weir? I found  the final log entry.
Peters sits at the workstation. Miller, DJ and Weir stand behind her, watching.
A jumpy, handheld camera view of: Gravity couch bay. Two crewmen checking electronics modul The ship is well-lit, clean, no sign of debris. The narra voice is excited and nervous.
We have reached safe distance and  are preparing to engage the gravity  drive and open the gateway...
The speaker is the mission  commander...
(quiet) John Kilpack.
Second Containment. A lone engineer finishes his check of the Core. He turns to the camera and gives a self-conscio "thumbs-up."
When you get this message, God  willing, we will reach the solar  system of Proxima Centauri...
I wonder if they ever made it.
Corridor. The entire original crew assembled, playing cat with the stuffed dog

I just want to say how proud I am of  my crew. I'd like to name my station  heads Chris Chambers, Janice Rubin,  Dick Smith, Tom Fender and Stacie  Collins. And to Bill Weir and all  the scientists that got us here.
Bridge. KILPACK addresses the camera. His face is flushed with excitement.
I... uh, I had something historic to  say, and I wrote it down but I... I  can't find it. Ave, atque, vale.  Hail and farewell.

A BURST of static... ...followed by an inhuman HOWL of FEEDBACK, like screamin hyaenas, almost alive. Through the swirl of static, the  suggestion of movement. Miller freezes the frame. He squints at the screen...
Obscured by static, the image is blurred beyond comprehen
What the hell is that? Dr. Weir?
I don't know.
I can run the image through a series  of filters, try to clean it up.
Do it.
Suddenly, the lights fade out. Dim emergency lighting sna on...
What's happening...?
A power drain --
We barely have enough power for life  support as it is, if we can't stop  the drain, we're not gonna make it.
The Core...!
Weir heads for the door.
Wait!
But Weir has vanished into the corridor.
The rest of you, stay here, I don't  want anyone else going near that  thing.
Miller follows after Weir.
The Second Containment Seal opens. Weir is about to enter when Miller stops him. He checks a Geiger counter. It is  silent.
No radiation. What's causing the  drain?
Weir crosses to a console. Frowns.
(shakes his head) The magnetic fields are holding.  Maybe a short in the fail-safe  circuit. I'll check it out.

Miller assists Weir in removing bolts from an access pane The panel falls away, revealing a cramped duct leading in the ship's circuitry. Weir climbs into the duct. Miller hands him a flashlight a toolkit.
We don't get the power back, our  air's gonna go bad.
Check the Core for radiation. Carbon  dioxide may be the least of our  worries.
Weir begins to crawl into the depths of the ship.
Weir's breath ECHOES in the cramped shaft. He counts off  circuit panels as he goes:
E-three... E-five... E-seven... where  are you...

Miller slogs through the coolant to the Core. Stares at i It remains metallic, mundane. He pulls out a Geiger counter and crosses to the reactor  shell. Examines a gleaming weld. The Geiger counter CLICK slowly: no leak.
A yellow light starts flashing on the engineering board.  Starck's eyes widen: the engineering sections flash  yellow...and green...
What the hell...
as the bio-scan goes wild.
(into intercom) Skipper, the bio-scan just went off  the scale...
Justin shakes on the bed in an epileptic fit. DJ rushes t him.
Justin! Can you hear me? Justin!
Justin's eyes remain unfocused, unseeing as he tries to s DJ leans in close, trying to hear him speak... Justin arches in agony and the words come in a strangled, tortured voice:
THE DARK IS COMING...
Weir stops before module E-12. Hears a faint HISSING and  POPPING.
There you are.

He uses a screwdriver to open up the module. Reveals a se of circuit boards. One SPARKS. Weir plucks the damaged ch and starts running a by-pass. His flashlight flickers. He bangs it against the duct wal It grows dimmer. Goes out.
Um. Captain Miller? I, uh, I seem to  have a problem with my light.
A single DRIP of water in the darkness...
(beat, hushed) Captain Miller?
Another DRIP, then a woman's VOICE like a distant echo:
Billy.
Weir starts at the sound. He recognizes the voice. She speaks again, no longer far away, but a close WHISPER his ear:
Billy. Help me. I'm so cold.
Weir's eyes open wide in hope and fear.
Even the emergency lights go out. Total darkness.
We just lost all power in here. Dr.  Weir...?

Miller's voice trails off as he looks towards the Core. A red glow reflects across his eyes. He takes a few steps a from the reactor. He stares... ...at the BURNING MAN, standing before the Core. The deep ROAR of its conflagration fills the containment. It slowly turns and raises its arm and points at Miller i accusation.
Don't leave me...
Miller stares as the Burning Man turns and vanishes into bulkhead, leaving the wall blackened and burned with his  passing.
Total darkness. Weir's breath ECHOES in the cramped metal space.
(a whisper) Claire...?
Weir bangs his flashlight. Again. Again...
Help me. I'm so cold.
The flashlight flickers... Claire's face is inches from Weir's.
So cold.
His flashlight flickers again, snaps on... She is gone. Weir lets his head fall to the floor of the  deck, breathing in ragged SOBS.
The crew, except for Cooper. DJ whets a scalpel against t leg of his jumpsuit, an unconscious gesture. FLICK. FLICK FLICK.
Carbon dioxide poisoning produces  hallucinations, impaired judgement...
Goddammit, DJ, it was not a  hallucination! I saw a man, he was  on fire. And then he disappeared.
Maybe one of the original crew?
No. It was someone else.
Who?
(ignoring the question) Dr. Weir, you were right there, you  must have heard something, seen  something...
No. I saw nothing.
I did.
All heads turn to her.
About an hour ago. In medical. I saw  my son. He was lying on one of the  examination tables and his legs  were... (she trails off)
Isn't it possible that you were  traumatized by finding the body on  the bridge?
I've seen bodies before. This is  different.
She falls silent, unwilling to say more.
Peters is right. Its like something  reaching into your mind. Seeing your  thoughts and making them real. Smith,  did you or Cooper experience anything  unusual?
Smith, leaning against the doorway:
I didn't see anything and I don't  have to see anything. This ship is  fucked.
Thank you for that scientific  analysis, Mister Smith.
(exploding) Hey! You don't need to be a scientist  figure it out...
Smith...
Weir's face is stone.
...you break all the laws of physics,  you think there won't be a price?  You already killed the first crew...
That's enough!

DJ lays one hand on Smith's shoulder to calm him... Smith reacts violently, turning on DJ, shoving him back. uses Smith's momentum to spin the pilot into the wall. He presses his scalpel just below Smith's ear...
DJ!!
DJ freezes. The scalpel falls from his hands. He releases Smith.
I'm sorry, I... I don't know why I  did that.
(wry) Carbon dioxide.
Smith goes for Weir.
He's fucking lying, you know  something...!
Miller heads him off, grabs him.
That's it, that's enough for one  day, Smith! I need you back on the  Clark, I need you calm, I need you  using your head, you make a mistake  out there, none of are getting home,  you understand?
Smith calms.
Sir.
Get outside, go back to work. I'll  join you shortly.
Smith leaves.
We're a long way from home and we're  in a bad place. Let's not make it  worse. If anyone has any constructive  suggestions, now is the time.
I think I can stabilize the fields  around the singularity, that should  prevent another power drain.
Do it.
To conserve our oxygen, we should  severely restrict our activity. Anyone  who can should get some sleep.
I don't need sleep, DJ. I need  answers.
Miller exits. Starck follows.
Miller...
(not slowing) What is it, Starck?
...I ran the bio-scan with the DNA/RNA  filter. The results were bio-readings  of indeterminate origin...
(simultaneous) "...bio-readings of indeterminate  origin," don't you have anything  useful to tell me?
I've got a theory.
Miller stops.
Go ahead.

There was a another surge in the bio- readings right before you... you saw  what you saw. We picked up a similar  readings right before the Clarke was  damaged. What if there were a  connection between the two? The  gravity waves, the hallucination,  all part of an defensive reaction,  like an immune system...
Miller starts walking again.
I don't need to hear this.
She rushes to follow.
Miller and Starck enter the Airlock Bay:
You've got to listen...
To what? What are you saying? This  ship is alive?
I didn't say that, I said the bio- readings correspond to what happened  to you, the ship is reacting to us...
We're hanging on by our fingernails  and you're giving me bullshit  stories...
She grabs him by the arm.
It's not bullshit, it's the only  conclusion the data supports...
Starck, do you know how crazy that  sounds? It's impossible.
I know that.
Beat. Miller allows himself to relax.
If you knew it was impossible, then  why'd you waste my time?
I thought you wanted an answer. And  that's the only one I have.
Miller pulls an EVA suit from the wall, starts putting it on.
What I want is to survive the next  ten hours.
(checks her watch) Nine hours and twenty-two minutes.
I'm going outside to work on the  Clark. And Starck... don't tell anyone  what you just told me. We've got  enough to worry about.
She nods. He locks his helmet into place.
Establish.
The ship seems to breathe. The lights flicker...
ANOTHER ANGLE. The ship seems to breathe. The lights  flicker...
ANOTHER ANGLE. The ship seems to breathe. The lights  flicker...

Peters has fallen asleep in her chair. On the threshold of hearing, a distant POUNDING. Not a  heartbeat. Metal on metal. Something trying to get out.  Something trying to get in. Peters wakes with a start.
Justin...?
She turns. Justin lies on the floor in a heap, completely covered by his sheet. She crosses to him. Pulls back the  sheet... Revealing empty nitrogen tanks.
Justin!

She looks up, eyes widening, as... The IV bottles fill with blood. Blood fills the X-ray  lightboxes, it surges up from gutters in the floor... And the pounding grows louder... LOUDER... almost to  Medical... The spell breaks and she RUNS...
Peters sprints, the SOUND BOOMING after her, almost on he heels...
Peters darts into the Bridge Antechamber. She SLAMS the  pressure door shut behind her, CUTTING OFF the sound. She turns. Weir, DJ, Starck look up from their work, star at her.
What's wrong?
You didn't hear it? You must have  heard it!
Heard what?
Beat. Peters starts to LAUGH, part hysteria, part relief.
Oh... nothing...
DJ crosses to Peters, concerned.
Sit down...
As he reaches out to touch her...

head_text.subj: BOOM. BOOM. BOOM. POUNDING ON THE DOOR ITSELF

text: Peters SCREAMS. DJ clutches her to him, backs away from t door. The POUNDING grows louder. LOUDER. The door vibrates with each blow Starck puts her hands over her ears. Peters SCR at the door.
Stop it! Stop it!
But the POUNDING intensifies, metal GROANING under incred pressure.
(shouting to be heard) What is it?
Weir slowly walks to the door.
What are you doing?
It wants me. I have to go.
He reaches for the door.

Starck grabs him. He tries to shake her off, but she trap his arm in a wrist-lock. He turns on her, his face furiou ...and the POUNDING stops. They remain frozen for a momen Afraid to breathe. Weir shakes the trance.
In our current environment, Dr. Weir,  self-control is an asset.
I'm alright. Please.
In the distance, the POUNDING begins again. Moving away f them. The ship systems station BEEPS. A warning light flashes o the console.
What is it?
The forward airlock.
(into radio) Miller, Smith, Cooper, any of you in  the airlock?
(radio) That's a negative, Starck.
(realization) Justin.
Peters, Starck and DJ rush from the Bridge, leaving Weir  behind.
Peters leads Starck and DJ down the corridor towards the  Forward Airlock bay. They round a corner in time to see a figure moving in the Airlock.
They race into the bay even as Justin steps into the Airl He is naked.
Justin, no!
Justin turns and stares through them with cold eyes. He  reaches out to the airlock control. The pressure door shuts with a HISS.
Miller, Smith and Cooper cling to the Lewis and Clark's h They carefully remove an access panel, revealing scorched wiring.
We'll have to re-route through the  port conduit to the APU.
What about the accumulator...?
Starck's VOICE breaks in:
(radio) Miller, come in...
What's going on in there, Starck?
(radio) Justin's in the airlock.
Starck at the intercom. The others huddle by the door.
(intercom) What?
He's awake, he's in the airlock,  he's not wearing a suit.
(to Cooper) Stay here! Don't stop working!
But Justin...
I'll get him.

Miller swings his body around, heads across the umbilicus the Event Horizon. He moves in great leaps, using the mag plates in his gloves and boots to keep from drifting off  into Neptune's thin atmosphere.
Starck works the airlock control panel without success.
He's engaged the override.
Can you shut it down?
She opens the Airlock access panel.
I'll try. DJ, you better get your  bag of tricks.
DJ nods, runs off. Peters bangs on the Airlock door.
Justin! Open the door!
Peters' voice barely penetrates the pressure door:
(muffled) Open the door!
Justin turns off the artificial gravity. He begins to flo gently.
Miller moves like a frantic spider across the surface of Event Horizon.
I'm on my way, Starck.
(radio) You better hurry. He's engaged the  override, we can't open the inner  door.
Miller curses under his breath, moves even faster...
Peters, against the window:
(muffled) The door, Justin! Open the door!
He fixes his gaze upon the outer airlock door. And beyond it, space. He speaks in a flat monotone:
Did you hear it?
They are stunned to hear his voice. Peters answers:
Yes. Yes, Justin, we heard it.
Keep him talking.
Do you know what it was?
(muffled) It gets inside you. It shows you  things... horrible things...
...can't describe it... there are no  words...
Weir sits alone, listening to the VOICES on the intercom.
(intercom) What, Justin, what shows you?
(intercom) It won't stop, it goes on and on and  on...
(intercom) What does?
(intercom) The dark inside me.
A LOW MOAN escapes Weir's lips. He cradles his head in hi hands.
Miller races across the surface of the Event Horizon, the only sounds, his LABOURED BREATHING, and Justin's torture VOICE, patched through on his radio:
(radio) ...It's inside and it eats and eats  until there's nothing left.
(radio) "The dark inside..."? I don't  understand.
(radio) From the Other Place...
The other crew, they're there, they're  waiting for me. They're waiting for  you. I won't go back there... I  won't...
Peters presses her face against the Airlock window, tryin to calm him:
Justin, look at me. Look at me. Open  this door.
DJ runs up with his medkit.
I don't think she can talk him down.  We need a sedative.
If he opens the outer door he'll  turn inside-out.
Starck's hands fly as she re-wires the circuits. Sweat be her face.
Almost got it.
(muffled) Come on, Baby-bear, open this door...
Justin looks at her with dead eyes. He reaches out to gen touch the glass between them.
If you could see the things I've  seen, you wouldn't try to stop me.  You'd come with me.
Justin's hand moves to the OUTER AIRLOCK DOOR control.  Hesitates... then floats to the OUTER AIRLOCK control. Hi it.
(muffled) NOOO!
A yellow warning light flashes. A warning klaxon WHOOPS,  deafening. Justin jerks his hands to his ears, closes his eyes...
Stand-by for decompression. Thirty  seconds...
Justin opens his eyes as if waking from a dream...
Hey, Mama-Bear... what are doing...?
And then he realizes where he is...and what is about to  happen.
Oh my god OH MY GOD...
Starck!
I can't! The inner door can't open  once the outer door has been  triggered, it would decompress the  entire ship!
(muffled) You gotta open, you gotta stop it,  please...
We have to do something, oh God...
(into radio) Skipper, Justin just activated the  door. It's on a thirty second delay...
Miller moves through the Event Horizon superstructure,  recklessly leaping from one beam to another, trying to bu up speed.
Patch me through to him.
(radio) Justin.
Skipper, you gotta help me...
Twenty seconds.
...tell them to open the door...
(radio) They can't do that Justin, now listen  carefully...

Miller moves faster and faster, his BREATH echoing in his helmet. He can see the exterior airlock just beyond a dee chasm in the ship's superstructure. If he misses this jum Justin will not be the only man to die today. He doesn't hesitate but leaps, soaring across the chasm  towards the airlock.
(radio) ...I don't want to die...!
You're not going to die! Not today!  I want you to do exactly as I say  and I'm gonna get you out of there,  alright?
But I can't... I gotta get out of  here... Skipper, please...
(radio) Justin. I won't let you die.
Miller's words give Justin hope. He regains some control.
Okay... okay...
Justin breathes hard and follows Miller's hurried  instructions:
(radio) Tuck yourself into a crouched  position, shut your eyes as tight as  you can!
Five seconds.
Miller lands on the superstructure opposite the exterior  airlock.
(radio) Exhale everything you got, Baby Bear,  we can't have any air in those lungs,  blow it all out...
Justin goes into a fetal crouch and covers his eyes.
Oh god --
He wheezes out all his air...

Miller squats on the girder, ready to push off. He focuse on the 5 meters of space between him and the airlock... The outer doors OPEN... The rush of escaping atmosphere carries Justin's body out Miller pushes off... catches Justin's body... sending the both back towards the open Airlock... Ice forms on Justin's body. His veins bulge. Blood founta from his noise and mouth, forming a red icicle over his f Miller pulls him into the Airlock. Five seconds have pass since the airlock door opened.
Miller closes the Airlock behind them. Air HISSES into th chamber. Justin's body hits the deck as "normal" gravity  exerts itself. Miller opens the Inner Door. Peters and DJ rush in.
Oh God... Justin...
DJ puts a tube in the Justin's mouth immediately, feeding him oxygen.
I've got a pulse, he's alive...
Pressure?
90 over 50 and falling... .
He's crashing...
Blood bubbles from Justin's mouth and eyes. He GASPS, the SCREAMS, spraying blood from his mouth.
He can breathe. That's good. Let's  get him to Medical, go, go!
Starck helps DJ and Peters carry Justin from the Airlock. Miller sits there, exhausted. Reaches up and pulls his he off.
Weir listens to
(intercom) Intubate, pure oxygen feed, get the  nitrogen out of his blood...
(intercom) His peritoneum has ruptured...
(intercom) One thing at a time, let's keep him  breathing. Start the drip, 15cc's  fibrinogen, Christ, he's bleeding  out...
One of the tanks has been activated. Swaddled in bandages Justin floats within, suspended in green gel. The others DJ, Starck, Peters, Miller, Weir -- look exhausted.
He'll live... if we ever make it  back.
We'll make it.
CO2 levels will reach toxic levels  in four hours.
Peters stands, looking at Justin's ravaged form floating the tank.
(gently) Peters. We need to know what happened  to the crew. Before it happens to  us.
(weakly) I'll get back to the log. But on the  bridge, I won't go back, back in  there...
Thanks.
Peters exits.
Justin said something about, "The  dark inside me..." What did he mean?
It means nothing.
Is that your "expert opinion?" The  only answer we've had out of you is  "I don't know."
Justin just tried to kill himself.  The man is clearly insane.
How would you explain your own  behavior?
What?
On the bridge. You said "it" wanted  you.
Weir glances at Justin...
But it's not Justin in the tank. It's his wife CLAIRE, na wet, dead. Weir stares at her.
I said that?
Yes. You did.
Weir blinks. Justin floats in the grav couch. Weir turns  back to the others.
I don't remember saying that. (covers with a joke) Maybe I'm insane, too.
Weir exits.
Miller follows Weir out of the Gravity Couch Bay.
I want to know what caused that noise.  I want to know why one of my crew  tried to throw himself out of the  airlock.
Thermal changes in the hull could  have caused the metal to expand and  contract very suddenly, causing  reverberations --
(exploding) That's bullshit and you know it! You  built this fucking ship and all I've  heard from you is bullshit!
What do you want me to say?
You said this ship creates a  gateway...
Yes...
To what? Where did this ship go?  Where did you send it?
I don't know...
Where has it been for the past seven  years?
I don't know...
The "Other Place," what is that...?
I DON'T KNOW! (beat, calm again) I don't know. There's a lot of things  going on here that I don't understand.  Truth takes time.
That's exactly what we don't have,  Doctor.
Miller moves through the maze of the ship, heading for th Bridge. As he reaches a junction, he hears... ...A DISTANT CRY...
Don't leave me...!
Miller wheels like a cat, staring wildly down the branchi corridors. Nothing. He is alone. Miller leans against the wall, sink to the floor, rests his head in his hands.
The grotesque ship continues it's orbit as the moon Trito eclipses the sun. Darkness swallows all.
DJ enters, checks Justin's display.
Any change?
DJ turns, surprised. Miller sits, barely visible in the d
No. No change. (beat) I've analyzed Justin's blood samples.  There's no evidence of excessive  levels of carbon dioxide. Or anything  else out of ordinary.
A grim LAUGH from Miller.
Of course not. Justin just climbed  into the airlock because he felt  like it. Just one of those things. (beat) I swore I'd never lose another man.  I came close today. Real close.
"Another man?" Who?
Miller nods, pulls his service medal from beneath his  jumpsuit.

It was on the Goliath. There was  this bosun, Corrick, a young guy, a  lot like Justin. Edmund Corrick,  from Decatur, Georgia. He got caught  when the pressure doors sealed, one  closed on his arm. Severed it at the  wrist. The pain of that must have  been... He passed out and...
Miller trails off. DJ waits patiently. Finally:

I, I tried to go back for him, to  save him, but I couldn't get to him  in time. The fire... Have you ever  seen fire in zero-gravity? It's like  a liquid, it slides over everything.  It was like a wave breaking over  him, a wave of fire. And then he was  gone. (beat) I never told anyone until now. But  this ship knew, DJ. It knows about  the Goliath, it knows about Corrick.  It knows our secrets. It knows what  we're afraid of. (beat, wan smile) And now you're going to tell me it's  carbon dioxide.
No.
Miller sees something in DJ's expression.
What is it?
I've been listening to the  transmission. And I think Houston  made a mistake in the translation.
Go on.
DJ plays the recording again. Stops it abruptly.
They thought it said, "Liberatis  me," "Save me," but it's not "me."  It's "tutemet:" "Save yourself."
It's not a distress call. It's a  warning.
It gets worse.
Miller stares at him.
It's very hard to make out, but listen  to this final part.
He plays the recording again.
Do you hear it? Right there.
Hear what?
It sounds like "ex infera:" "ex,"  from; "infera," the ablative case of  "inferi." "Hell."
"Save yourself. From Hell." (beat) What are you saying, are you saying  that this ship is possessed?

No. I don't believe in that sort of  thing. (beat) But if Dr. Weir is right, this ship  has passed beyond the boundaries of  our universe, of reality. Who knows  where this ship has been... What  it's seen... (beat) And what it's brought back with it.
DJ looks at Miller. He does not have an answer. The inter
(intercom) Captain Miller, we're ready to  repressurize the Clark.
(into intercom) On my way.
Miller stands in his EVA suit in the darkened bridge. He  twists a manual valve.
Alright, Cooper.
Cooper looks at Smith.
Cross your fingers.
A moment later, mist flows from the vents into the bridge filling it with atmosphere. Miller watches the pressure r on his suit gauge.
(radio) It's holding... She's holding...!
(radio) We're still venting trace gasses,  gimme twenty minutes to plug the  hole.
You got it, Coop.
Miller removes his helmet. Breathes deep.
Back in business.
Peters sits in front of the screen. The log is still  distorted. Frustrated, she types in a series of instructions. Get to her feet.
You got any coffee?
It's cold.
I don't care.
Behind Peters, the process refines, accelerates... pieces coming together like a jigsaw... Peters turns around. Sees the screen. The coffee slips fr her hand to the floor.
(tiny voice) Starck...
Starck turns, sees the screen.
Sweet Jesus. Miller... MILLER!
Miller, Starck, DJ watch the video. Peters turns away,  miserable. Unable to watch...

still distorted by static and roll, but finally lucid: FO ORIGINAL CREW of the Event Horizon. On the Bridge. ONE MAN dislocates his shoulder with a WET POPPING sound he shoves his arm down his own throat. Blood bubbles from his nose. With a SHUCKING sound, he pulls his stomach out his mouth...
